sen.j: トヨクモノは、日本神話の天地開闢 (日本神話)の段に登場する神 (神道)である。
sen.e: Toyokumono is a Shinto deity appearing in the story of the creation of heaven and earth (the Japanese Mythology).
Toyokumono is a Shinto deity appearing in the story of the creation of heaven and earth (the Japanese Mythology).
Toyokumono is a Shinto deity appearing in the story of the creation of heaven and earth (the Japanese Mythology).

sen.j: 神代七代のうちの一柱。
sen.e: He is a god of Kamiyonanayo (Seven Generations).
He is a god of Kamiyonanayo (Seven Generations).
He is a god of Kamiyonanayo (Seven Generations).

sen.j: 古事記では豊雲野神（とよくもののかみ）、日本書紀では豊斟渟尊（とよくむぬのみこと）と表記される。
sen.e: Toyokumono is described as Toyokumono-no-kami 豊雲野神 in Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), and as Toyokumune-no-mikoto 豊斟渟尊 in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).
Toyokumono is described as Toyokumono-no-kami 豊雲野神 in Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), and as Toyokumune-no-mikoto 豊斟渟尊 in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).
Toyokumono is described as Toyokumono no kami 豊雲野神 in Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters), and as Toyokumune no mikoto 豊斟渟尊 in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).
Descriptions in mythology
Descriptions in mythology

sen.j: 古事記では、神代七代の二番目、国之常立神の次に化生したとしている。
sen.e: Toyokumono was the second one to come into being as Kamiyonanayo following Kuninotokotachi-no-kami.
Toyokumono was the second one to come into being as Kamiyonanayo following Kuninotokotachi-no-kami.
In Kojiki, Toyokumono was the second one to come into being as Kamiyonanayo following Kuninotokotachi no kami.
sen.cmt: In Kojiki補足ハイフン削除

sen.j: 国之常立神と同じく独神であり、すぐに身を隠したとある。
sen.e: He was regarded as Hitorigami (a kami which came into being alone) like Kuninotokotachi-no-kami, and hid himself away just after coming into being.
He was regarded as Hitorigami (a kami which came into being alone) like Kuninotokotachi-no-kami, and hid himself away just after coming into being.
He was regarded as Hitorigami (a kami which came into being alone) like Kuninotokotachi no kami, and hid himself away just after coming into being.

sen.j: 日本書紀本文では、天地開闢の後、国常立尊、国狭槌尊の次の三番目に豊斟渟尊が化生したとしており、これらの三柱の神は男神であると記している。
sen.e: The main text of Nihonshoki describes that after the creation of heaven and earth, Toyokumune-no-mikoto was the third one to come into being following Kuninotokotachi-no-mikoto and Kuninosatsuchi-no-mikoto, and these three were male deities.

The main text of Nihonshoki describes that after the creation of heaven and earth, Toyokumune-no-mikoto was the third one to come into being following Kuninotokotachi-no-mikoto and Kuninosatsuchi-no-mikoto, and these three were male deities.

The main text of Nihonshoki describes that after the creation of heaven and earth, Toyokumune no mikoto was the third one to come into being following Kuninotokotachi no mikoto and Kuninosatsuchi no mikoto, and these three were male deities.

sen.j: 第一の一書では、国常立尊・国狭槌尊の次の三番目に化生した神を豊国主尊（とよくにぬしのみこと）とし、別名がして豊組野尊（とよくむののみこと）、豊香節野尊（とよかぶののみこと）、浮経野豊買尊（うかぶののとよかふのみこと）、豊国野尊（とよくにののみこと）、豊野齧尊（とよかぶののみこと）、葉木国野尊（はこくにののみこと）、見野尊（みののみこと）であると記している。
sen.e: According to Arufumi Vol. 1 (supplement volumes of explanatory notes in Nihonshoki), it was Toyokuninushi-no-mikoto who was the third one to come into being following Kuninotokotachi-no-mikoto and Kuninosatsuchi-no-mikoto; his another names are described as follows: Toyokumuno-no-mikoto 豊組野尊, Toyokabuno-no-mikoto 豊香節野尊, Ukabunono-toyoko-no-mikoto 浮経野豊買尊, Toyokunino-no-mikoto 豊国野尊, Toyokabuno-no-mikoto 豊野齧尊, Hakokunino-no-mikoto 葉木国野尊, and Mino-no-mikoto 見野尊.

According to Arufumi Vol. 1 (supplement volumes of explanatory notes in Nihonshoki), it was Toyokuninushi-no-mikoto who was the third one to come into being following Kuninotokotachi-no-mikoto and Kuninosatsuchi-no-mikoto; his another names are described as follows: Toyokumuno-no-mikoto 豊組野尊, Toyokabuno-no-mikoto 豊香節野尊, Ukabunono-toyoko-no-mikoto 浮経野豊買尊, Toyokunino-no-mikoto 豊国野尊, Toyokabuno-no-mikoto 豊野齧尊, Hakokunino-no-mikoto 葉木国野尊, and Mino-no-mikoto 見野尊.

According to Arufumi Vol. 1 (supplement volumes of explanatory notes in Nihonshoki), it was Toyokuninushi no mikoto who was the third one to come into being following Kuninotokotachi no mikoto and Kuninosatsuchi no mikoto; his another names are described as follows: Toyokumuno no mikoto 豊組野尊, Toyokabuno no mikoto 豊香節野尊, Ukabunono toyoko no mikoto 浮経野豊買尊, Toyokunino no mikoto 豊国野尊, Toyokabuno no mikoto 豊野齧尊, Hakokunino no mikoto 葉木国野尊, and Mino no mikoto 見野尊.

sen.j: 「豊」がつく名前が多く、豊雲野神・豊斟渟尊と同一神格と考えられている。
sen.e: Since many of their names include the kanji character "toyo 豊," they are regarded to have the same divinity as Toyokumono-no-kami or Toyokumune-no-mikoto has.
Since many of their names include the kanji character "toyo 豊," they are regarded to have the same divinity as Toyokumono-no-kami or Toyokumune-no-mikoto has.
Since many of their names include the kanji character 'toyo' (豊), they are regarded to have the same divinity as Toyokumono no kami or Toyokumune no mikoto has.

sen.j: 第二から第六の一書には、同一神とみられる神名は登場しない。
sen.e: From Arufumi Vol. 2 to Vol. 6, there are no god's name, which seems to be identical to this deity.
From Arufumi Vol. 2 to Vol. 6, there are no god's name, which seems to be identical to this deity.
From Arufumi Vol. 2 to Vol. 6, there are no god's name, which seems to be identical to this deity.

sen.j: 古事記・日本書紀とも、これ以降、豊雲野神が神話に登場することはない。
sen.e: From this point forward, Toyokumono-no-kami never appears in any stories of Kojiki and Nihonshoki.
From this point forward, Toyokumono-no-kami never appears in any stories of Kojiki and Nihonshoki.
From this point forward, Toyokumono no kami never appears in any stories of Kojiki and Nihonshoki.

sen.j: 神話にはほとんど名前しか登場しないので、その神格については神名しか手がかりがなく、様々な解釈が行われている。
sen.e: Since Toyokumono appears only by the name in mythology, and there is nothing except his name that offers any clue as to his divinity, he is interpreted in various ways.
Since Toyokumono appears only by name in mythology, and there is nothing except his name that offers any clue as to his divinity, and can be interpreted in various ways.
Since Toyokumono appears only by name in mythology, and there is nothing except his name that offers any clue as to his divinity, and can be interpreted in various ways.

sen.j: 『古事記伝』では、「豊国野尊」の別名に注目して、豊かに富み足りた国の意であるとしている。
sen.e: Taking his another name of Toyokunino-no-mikoto as an example, "Kojikiden" (Commentaries on the Kojiki) describes that the name symbolizes an abundant profitable country.
Taking his other name of Toyokunino-no-mikoto as an example, "Kojikiden" (Commentaries on the Kojiki) describes that the name symbolizes an abundant profitable country.
Taking his other name of Toyokunino no mikoto as an example, "Kojikiden" (Commentaries on the Kojiki) describes that the name symbolizes an abundant profitable country.

sen.j: 「クモ」「クミ」「クニ」などは「籠る」「組む」の意味で、浮脂のように漂っていたものが次第に固まる様子を表したものという説
sen.e: One theory is that "Kumo," "Kumi," or "Kuni" used in his name mean "seclude," or "assemble," symbolizing the way something drifting like floating grease gradually sticks together.
One theory is that "Kumo," "Kumi," or "Kuni" used in his name means "seclude," or "assemble," symbolizing the way something drifting like floating grease gradually sticks together.
One theory is that 'Kumo,' 'Kumi,' or 'Kuni' used in his name means 'seclude,' or 'assemble,' symbolizing the way something drifting like floating grease gradually sticks together.

sen.j: 「クモ」「クム」などは「木間（こま）」の意味で、樹木が生えている土地を表すという説
sen.e: Another theory is that "Kumo" or "Kumu" used in his name mean "among the trees," symbolizing the land where trees grow.
Another theory is that "Kumo" or "Kumu" used in his name mean "among the trees," symbolizing the land where trees grow.
